author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Republicans Sharpen Their Message on Ukraine
description: Party leaders think that tying President Biden’s handling of the war to his domestic woes could be a potent argument with voters in the fall.
content: Immediately after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the political debate in the U.S. was a free-for-all. Democrats and some Republicans aligned behind President Biden exhibiting what was once considered a traditional show of unity in a crisis. Other Republicans blasted Biden as weak and insufficiently tough on Russia. In perhaps the strangest twist, still other Republicans, including Donald Trump, seemed to sympathize with Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Unlikely to Tip
description: Nam Jin Yoon’s Saturday puzzle can keep a secret.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a very elegant grid, Nam Jin Yoon’s sixth Saturday construction in a row for The Times. If you find your eyes drawn to the arrowhead-like set of squares in the northwest corner, that’s because the puzzle has diagonal symmetry, using the northwest-southeast diagonal as its axis. This arrangement had a strange effect on my solve, as I mentally swept the four long answers at 12-Across, 12-Down, 14-Across and 14-Down to the side and filled them all in at the very end, using a lot of crosses. I consider all four of those entries really good stumpers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Mastercard and Visa suspend operations in Russia.
description: Russian-issued cards will no longer work in other countries, and purchases from Russian vendors by cardholders in other countries will be cut off.
content: Mastercard and Visa said they would suspend operations in Russia, essentially severing cardholders there from transactions outside the country in response to the invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anastasiia Lapatina
title: Putin Picked the Wrong Country to Mess With
description: Ukrainians are heroically united in repelling the Russian invasion.
content: PRZEMYSL, Poland — For months, Ukraine worried and agonized about a potential invasion. But in just over one week of hellish war, Ukrainians revealed themselves to be some of the bravest people in the world. Against Russia’s full-scale assault, civilians across the country have been courageously, even terrifyingly, defiant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Launches Ballistic Missile, South Korea Says
description: The launch is North Korea’s second missile test in a week and comes only days before the presidential election in South Korea.
content: SEOUL — North Korea on Saturday launched a ballistic missile toward the sea off its east coast, its second missile test in a week, South Korean defense officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: We’re Entering a Period of Relatively Low Covid Risk for Kids
description: Despite so-so vaccine news for children 5 to 11.
content: Earlier this week, I saw this Times headline skitter across my Twitter feed: “Pfizer Shot Is Far Less Effective in 5- to 11-Year-Olds Than in Older Kids, New Data Show.” An online preprint of a study of 852,384 fully vaccinated children 12 to 17 years old and 365,502 children 5 to 11 years old in New York State found that although kids in that 5 to 11 range were protected “against severe disease,” they weren’t well protected against infection from the Omicron variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Parlor Trick
description: Matthew Stock and Will Nediger practice their crossword wizardry on us.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today we have a visually unusual challenge by two excellent constructors, Matthew Stock and Will Nediger, who are collaborating for the first time in The New York Times. According to the puzzle’s print introduction, the two connected online and developed a theme conceived by Mr. Stock, using direct messages on Twitter and swapping grids until they were both happy. They have yet to meet, even on video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Rabasca Roepe
title: You Quit Your Job, but You Still Need a Retirement Plan
description: Millions of American workers said goodbye to their bosses last year. If you’re one, don’t lose sight of your savings and investment goals.
content: When she realized she wanted to quit her job at a San Francisco software company, Anna Rider was taking care of two babies: a food blog that she wanted to grow, and her actual child — the son she had five months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: Putin’s Fear of Free Speech Speaks Volumes
description: What we are seeing in Russia is a reminder of why protecting free speech is so important.
content: On Friday, the Russian government blocked access to Twitter, Facebook and multiple news sites, in an effort to stop people from speaking out against the war in Ukraine. The state also shut down the pillars of the country’s independent media, including the radio station Echo of Moscow that was launched by Soviet dissidents in 1990. And on Friday, the Duma passed a law punishing anyone who spreads “false information” about the Russian military, which could include anyone calling what is taking place in Ukraine a “war,” with a possible 15 years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Blinken Arrives in Poland to Gauge Additional U.S. Aid for Ukraine
description: The Russian invasion has pushed more than one million refugees to flee Ukraine for neighboring nations.
content: KORCZOWA, Poland — With a line of refugees streaming into Poland behind them, the top American and Ukrainian diplomats met at Ukraine’s border on Saturday in a brief but extraordinary encounter to assess what additional support and protection the United States might deliver to address Russia’s invasion, which appeared certain to continue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski
title: U.S. intelligence weighs Putin’s two years of extreme pandemic isolation as a factor in his wartime mind-set.
description: Analysts are debating whether the Russian leader’s ambitions and appetite for risk have been altered by his long-held Covid bubble, or by his urgency to secure a legacy, or both.
content: The White House effort to design a strategy to confront Russia over its invasion of Ukraine is linked to an urgent re-examination by intelligence agencies of President Vladimir V. Putin’s mental state. The debate is over whether his ambitions and appetite for risk have been altered by two years of Covid isolation, or by a sense that this may be his best moment to rebuild Russia’s sphere of influence and secure his legacy. Or both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. and Allies Discuss Security of Ukraine’s Leaders Amid Fears for Zelensky’s Safety
description: Concerns about the line of succession were prompted in part because President Volodymyr Zelensky insists he will not be evacuated.
content: WASHINGTON — Allied governments have been discussing how to secure the line of succession in Ukraine in the event President Volodymyr Zelensky is captured or killed by Russian forces, according to officials from multiple governments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley
title: China Outlines Plan to Stabilize Economy in Crucial Year for Xi
description: China calls for heavy government spending and lending, as its leaders seek to project confidence in the face of global uncertainty over the pandemic and war in Ukraine.
content: BEIJING — Plowing past global anxieties over the war engulfing Ukraine, China set its economy on a course of steady expansion for 2022, prioritizing growth, job creation and increased social welfare in a year when the national leader, Xi Jinping, is poised to claim a new term in power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Maggy Hurchalla, Formidable Florida Environmentalist, Dies at 81
description: She fought to protect the wilderness she loved, tangling with developers. One case led to a $4.4 million judgment against her.
content: The classic Maggy Hurchalla introduction would go something like this: “Come to my house,” she’d say. “We’ll go kayaking.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Nocera
title: Why American Mask Makers Are Going Out of Business
description: Efforts to make the supply chain more resilient after pandemic shortages are no match for low-price foreign products, the companies say.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How to Stop a Nuclear War
description: It’s often better to constrain yourself than to limit your enemy’s choices.
content: In September 1983, Stanislav Petrov was a lieutenant colonel in the Soviet military, assigned to the command center that monitored early-warning satellites over the United States. During one of his shifts, the alarms went off: The Americans had seemingly launched five Minuteman intercontinental ballistic missiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: The Best Time to Use Your Airline Miles? Now.
description: If you’re thinking of traveling and you’ve got points or miles sitting in airline and credit card accounts, the time to cash in may have arrived. Here’s what you need to know.
content: Frances Meredith of Raleigh, N.C. used a branded American Airlines credit card for everything from groceries to medical expenses during the pandemic, piling up points with nowhere to spend them. That meant she had plenty to redeem when her family of four decided it was time for a winter getaway to Miami. Although the seats were pricey at 50,000 points each, Dr. Meredith, an internist, was excited to save money by using her rewards balance. “It was easy. There were lots of seats,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Tony Walton, Award-Winning Stage and Screen Designer, Dies at 87
description: He worked with the directors Mike Nichols, Bob Fosse and Jerry Zaks, winning three Tony Awards and an Oscar for “All That Jazz.”
content: Tony Walton, a production designer who brought a broad visual imagination to the creation of distinct onstage looks for Broadway shows over a half-century, earning him three Tony Awards, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: On Ukraine, I Know What I Don’t Know
description: Sometimes it is better to listen than to speak.
content: You may have noticed, as readers of this newsletter (and presumably of my column as well), that I have not said or written much about the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Mitchell Ryan, Who Played the Villain in ‘Lethal Weapon,’ Dies at 88
description: Mr. Ryan, who appeared in the TV series “Dark Shadows,” played a brutal businessman in  “Santa Barbara” and a wealthy father in the sitcom “Dharma & Greg.”
content: Mitchell Ryan, an actor known for his role in the gothic soap opera “Dark Shadows” and who played a heroin-dealing retired general in the action movie “Lethal Weapon,” died at his home in Los Angeles on Friday. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave and Vjosa Isai
title: These Are the Cities in Ukraine Facing Russian Attacks
description: About two-thirds of Ukraine’s population of 44 million people lived in cities before Russia’s invasion began. Now many urban areas are in the cross hairs of war.
content: Blackened and bombed-out apartment towers. Families huddled together in subway stations. Downtown streets made silent, with shuttered cafes and nightclubs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: A Paranoid Person’s Guide to Preparing for Digital Danger
description: Russia’s attack may have you wondering what will happen if the conflict spills into cyberthreats beyond Ukraine’s borders. Here’s what you can do to ease your mind.
content: What if the lights go out? Or A.T.M. networks go down? Or digital giants like Google that I trust with vital information come under attack?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Fast-food chains and food producers stay open in Russia, and mostly quiet about Ukraine.
description: Many fast-food chains are facing growing pressure on social media platforms and from large investors to halt operations in Russia.
content: While technology giants like Apple and luxury retailers like  Hermès have quickly moved to pause sales or shutter stores in Russia over the invasion of Ukraine, most U.S. food companies and fast-food chains have remained open — and largely silent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: How Moms to Be Get to Act More Like Dads
description: The liberation of being pregnant on Zoom and not in the office.
content: For the past nine months, I have been pregnant. But I have not — for the most part — been pregnant at work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Alice von Hildebrand, Conservative Catholic Philosopher, Dies at 98
description: She was critical of abortion rights and gay rights, and called on women to change the world by embracing what she called feminine virtues.
content: The Roman Catholic philosopher Alice von Hildebrand lived to be 98, but her life almost ended one night in June 1940, when she was just 17.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Niraj Chokshi
title: Aeroflot says it will suspend international flights.
description: Russia’s airline industry has been hit hard as countries around the world have imposed sanctions on the country for its invasion of Ukraine.
content: Russia’s state airline, Aeroflot, said on Saturday that it would suspend all international flights from Tuesday “due to additional circumstances that prevent the performance of flights.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: Hollywood Bets Big on the Bad Entrepreneur
description: With limited series like “The Dropout,” “WeCrashed” and “Super Pumped,” the culture is saturated with ripped-from-the-headlines tales of self-immolating moguls.
content: “I’m not a bad guy,” the Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg (Jesse Eisenberg) insists at the end of “The Social Network,” the 2010 film that defined the cultural response to young tech billionaires. Zuckerberg’s thoughtful lawyer (Rashida Jones), an invented character who serves largely to adjudicate Zuckerberg’s personality, assures him that she doesn’t think he’s a jerk: “You’re just trying so hard to be one.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Tennessee, ‘Maus’ Fight Is Part of Bigger Battle
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 5, 2022.
content: “Not being able to speak to the things that I think are really important — not being able to express myself — is a little bit frustrating at times when it seems like everyone else is having no trouble expressing themselves louder and louder.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: While Canada Welcomes Refugees, Its Door Is Far From Wide Open
description: The war in Ukraine may bring another wave of asylum seekers to Canada, but they will face many controls and restrictions.
content: By Friday afternoon, one million people had fled Ukraine, mostly to neighboring countries, according to estimates from the U.N. refugee agency, U.N.H.C.R. As with other recent wars, resettlement groups in Canada are preparing to receive many of those who are expected to land here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Meeting with Congress, Zelensky asks for more jets and a no-fly zone.
description: The meeting, conducted via Zoom, was the first time President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine had addressed both houses of Congress since Russia’s invasion began.
content: WASHINGTON — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine spoke with more than 300 members of Congress on Saturday, imploring them to ban the importation of Russian oil and to send more jets to his country, according to lawmakers on the call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Jonathan Abrams
title: Brittney Griner, Star W.N.B.A. Center, Is Detained in Russia
description: Russian customs officials said a U.S. basketball player had vape cartridges containing hashish oil in her luggage. A Russian news agency identified the player as Griner.
content: WASHINGTON — Russia said on Saturday that it had detained an American basketball player — later identified as Phoenix Mercury center Brittney Griner — on drug charges, entangling a U.S. citizen’s fate in the dangerous confrontation between Russia and the West over Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Natalie Kitroeff and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: U.S. Officials Travel to Venezuela, a Russia Ally, as the West Isolates Putin
description: The trip is the highest-level visit by American officials to Caracas in years, driven by a desire to separate Russia from its remaining Latin American allies.
content: Senior U.S. officials are traveling to Venezuela on Saturday to meet with the government of President Nicolás Maduro, according to people familiar with the matter, as the Biden administration steps up efforts to separate Russia from its remaining international allies amid a widening standoff over Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: A Welcome Steeped in History: Ukrainian Refugees Arrive in Germany
description: Berlin has become a major hub for refugees from Ukraine, welcoming them with an outpouring of help. The response stirs memories of both bright and dark chapters of German history.
content: BERLIN — After an anxious eight-day journey fleeing a war that has since swallowed his hometown in eastern Ukraine, the welcome as he stepped off a train at Berlin Central Station felt faintly surreal to 15-year-old Dima Chornii.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ismail Khan and Salman Masood
title: Pakistan Identifies Peshawar Suicide Bomber and Network, Police Say
description: The attack at a Shiite mosque, claimed by an ISIS affiliate, killed at least 63 people and left nearly 200 wounded.
content: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Pakistani police investigators said on Saturday that they had identified the suicide bomber and the network behind the deadly blast on Friday at a Shiite mosque in Peshawar, in northwestern Pakistan, that left at least 63 dead and nearly 200 wounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum, John Koblin and Tiffany Hsu
title: Several Western news organizations suspend operations in Russia.
description: BBC and Bloomberg News were among the media outlets that instructed Russia-based reporters to cease news gathering after a new law cracked down on news and free speech.
content: Several Western media organizations moved on Friday to suspend their journalistic operations in Russia in the wake of a harsh new crackdown on news and free speech by President Vladimir V. Putin’s government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: In Ukraine’s West, Lviv Makes Itself a Vital Rear Base
description: Spared direct attacks so far, the city has become a transit point for thousands of fleeing refugees and for men and supplies headed to the front lines.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Municipal workers were wrapping statues in protective coverings and boarding up the stained-glass windows of the many churches that fill this historic European city in western Ukraine, as the population readied for war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah and Valerie Hopkins
title: Zelensky criticizes NATO over its rejection of a no-fly zone.
description: “All the people who will die from this day will die because of you, as well,” the Ukrainian president told NATO leaders in a video shared on social media.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine criticized NATO late Friday night over its rejection of a no-fly zone, hours after the alliance announced it would not intervene by air or land for fear of creating a conflict with Russia that could spill into other parts of Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson
title: Russians Seize Europe’s Biggest Nuclear Plant and Gain in the South as More Ukrainians Flee
description: The Russian military advance in Ukraine sowed more destruction and chaos, pointing to a worsening conflict, as the Kremlin also moved to restrict how it’s reported at home.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Russian forces in Ukraine seized Europe’s biggest nuclear power plant on Friday, tightened their noose around the capital and threatened more southern cities in their march to control the Black Sea coast, intensifying the deadly destruction and chaos from the eight-day-old invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Actress Morena Baccarin Cooks a Brazilian Stew
description: The actress stars in the NBC thriller, “The Endgame.”
content: “If I take these home to my kids and they don’t like them, I’m going to kill them,” the actress Morena Baccarin said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: The 2 Political Operatives at the Center of a New Jersey Murder Mystery
description: As Sean Caddle has now admitted, sinister plots were more than just idle fantasy to him.
content: In 2015, six years before Sean Caddle, a New Jersey campaign consultant, wound up at the center of the state’s most talked-about murder mystery, he began what seemed to be an unusual business venture. He called it Chainsaw Productions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Finland, Non-NATO and Nervous, Discusses Defense With Biden
description: “We usually don’t start wars,” President Sauli Niinisto of Finland said as the leaders spoke amid the war in Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Biden met in the Oval Office on Friday afternoon with Sauli Niinisto, the president of the non-NATO member and increasingly nervous Finland, Mr. Biden tried to put his guest at ease with a little banter recalling something that Barack Obama once said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: TikTok Is Gripped by the Violence and Misinformation of Ukraine War
description: The Chinese-owned video app is dealing with a flood of war videos and the question of whether it is spreading unverified information.
content: Bre Hernandez used to scan TikTok for videos of makeup tutorials and taco truck reviews. Since Russia invaded Ukraine, the 19-year-old has spent hours each day scrolling the app for war videos, watching graphic footage of Ukrainian tanks firing on Russian troops and civilians running away from enemy gunfire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How to Negotiate Your Rent (Which Is Probably Going Up)
description: Brokers insist that negotiations are possible, even in a competitive market. Here are some tips from the experts.
content: Q: The lease on my daughter’s Midtown Manhattan apartment expires in May, and she is concerned about a rent hike. When she signed the lease, she got two months of free rent. Now, comparable units in the building are renting for 35 percent more than what she’s paying. Could the landlord really raise her rent that much? Can she negotiate?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Florida Fire Consumes 1,400 Acres and Continues to Grow
description: By Saturday afternoon, more than 24 hours after the fire began, dry conditions and high winds were continuing to make it hard to contain the flames.
content: Over 600 homes have been evacuated in Bay County on the Florida Panhandle as a fast-moving wildfire that has been burning since Friday afternoon continued to resist containment efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Ex-Amtrak Engineer Acquitted in Philadelphia Crash That Killed 8
description: Brandon Bostian was at the controls of the train, which was speeding at more than 100 miles per hour through a curved section when it crashed, the authorities said.
content: A former Amtrak engineer who was operating a speeding train that derailed in Philadelphia in 2015, killing eight people, was acquitted on Friday of involuntary manslaughter and related charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Robbins
title: Wildlife Personalities Play a Role in Nature
description: Studies help explore the ways that animals — whether bold or shy, aggressive or meek, interact with their environment.
content: In August, a mountain lion was sighted several times prowling the suburbs of New Canaan, Conn., and not for the first time. A decade ago, a young mountain lion made its way to Connecticut, prowling more than 1,500 miles from the Black Hills of South Dakota, before it was killed crossing a highway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Here are the latest developments in the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
description: LVIV, Ukraine — As his troops continued to run into stiff resistance in Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia delivered an ominous message to Ukrainians on Saturday, telling government leaders they might lose their statehood and likening the withering sanctions imposed on his country to a “declaration of war.”
content: LVIV, Ukraine — As his troops continued to run into stiff resistance in Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia delivered an ominous message to Ukrainians on Saturday, telling government leaders they might lose their statehood and likening the withering sanctions imposed on his country to a “declaration of war.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Stiefvater
title: Middle Grade Fiction That Sees the Forest for the Trees
description: In Pam Muñoz Ryan’s “Solimar,” Ben Okri’s “Every Leaf a Hallelujah” and Marjorie Liu’s “Wingbearer,” saving humanity can begin with a single sprout.
content: SOLIMARThe Sword of the MonarchsBy Pam Muñoz Ryan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Toobin
title: William P. Barr’s Good Donald Trump and Bad Donald Trump
description: William P. Barr’s memoir, “One Damn Thing After Another,” recounts his life and, in particular, his time as Donald Trump’s attorney general.
content: ONE DAMN THING AFTER ANOTHERMemoirs of an Attorney GeneralBy William P. Barr
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Zelensky and Trump: Two Performers, One Hero
description: A fake tough guy versus the real deal.
content: WASHINGTON — History is full of strange odysseys and intersections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Ronen Bergman
title: Israeli prime minister visits Moscow for talks with Putin on Ukraine.
description: Prime Minister Naftali Bennett of Israel met for three hours with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, the Israeli leader’s office said.
content: Prime Minister Naftali Bennett of Israel traveled to Moscow to meet at the Kremlin with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, according to Israeli and Russian officials, a rare moment of diplomacy in a war that has stretched into its second week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz, Marc Santora, Evan Hill and Alexander Cardia
title: Ukrainian protesters take to the streets in occupied Kherson.
description: Kherson was the first major city to fall to Russian forces and the protests are presenting a challenge to the new authority.
content: ODESSA, Ukraine — Kherson, in southern Ukraine, was the first major city to fall to Russian forces and now popular street protests are presenting a challenge to the new authority there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson
title: Russian Forces Pound Civilians, as Putin Likens Sanctions to a ‘Declaration of War’
description: Despite a cease-fire, Russia shelled near humanitarian corridors meant for civilians to escape an embattled city, Ukraine says, while the Russian leader also warned about a no-fly zone.
content: ODESSA, Ukraine — President Vladimir V. Putin warned on Saturday that crippling economic sanctions imposed by the West were “akin to a declaration of war,” as the Russian military pummeled civilian targets and continued shelling near the first protected routes intended to allow besieged Ukrainians to flee, apparently violating a cease-fire that had been agreed to only hours earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Florida Senate Passes Voting Bill to Create Election Crimes Agency
description: The bill would make Florida one of the first states to have a force dedicated to election crimes and voter fraud, despite such offenses being exceedingly rare.
content: The Florida Senate passed a sweeping new bill overhauling the state’s electoral process, adding new restrictions to the state election code and establishing a law enforcement office dedicated solely to investigating election crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Neil Vigdor
title: California Woman Is Charged With Faking Her Own Abduction in 2016
description: Three weeks after she vanished, Sherri Papini was found over 140 miles from her home. According to the authorities, her account of being kidnapped was a lie.
content: She said that her captors had leashed her to a pole inside a closet, a bucket of kitty litter serving as her toilet. Then came the beatings. And when she tried to escape, she told investigators, she was branded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: True Stories
description: Why are so many drama series based on real-life events?
content: “Atlanta” returns for its third season on March 24, and I’ve got it marked on my calendar, not just because it’s been nearly four years since the last season, but because it stands out as an original series in the flood of docudramatic reimaginations of real-life events that has overtaken streaming platforms of late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Too Close to Putin? Institutions Vet Artists, Uncomfortably.
description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has led arts organizations to reconsider who performs, forcing them to confront questions about free speech and policing political views.
content: In Canada, an acclaimed 20-year-old Russian pianist’s concert was canceled amid concerns about his silence on the invasion of Ukraine. The music director of an orchestra in Toulouse, France — who is also the chief conductor at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow — was instructed to clarify his position on the war before his next appearance. In New York, Anna Netrebko, one of opera’s biggest stars, saw her reign at the Metropolitan Opera end after she declined to denounce President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler, Katrin Bennhold and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: How the West Marshaled a Stunning Show of Unity Against Russia
description: In a few frantic days, the West threw out the playbook it used for decades against the Kremlin and isolated Russia with unparalleled sanctions and penalties.
content: LONDON — The day after Russian tanks and troops poured across the Ukrainian border on Feb. 24, NATO leaders received a deeply frightening message. The alliance’s secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg, opened an emergency video summit by warning that President Vladimir V. Putin had “shattered peace in Europe” and that from now on, he would openly contest the continent’s security order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: ‘I Just Can’t Stand By’: American Veterans Join the Fight in Ukraine
description: All across the country, small groups of military veterans are hungry for what they see as a righteous fight to defend freedom against an autocratic aggressor.
content: Hector served two violent tours in Iraq as a United States Marine, then got out, got a pension and a civilian job, and thought he was done with military service. But on Friday, he boarded a plane for one more deployment, this time as a volunteer in Ukraine. He checked in several bags filled with rifle scopes, helmets and body armor donated by other veterans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Hawgood
title: What Is ‘Bigorexia’?
description: A social media diet of perfect bodies is spurring some teenage boys to form muscle dysmorphia.
content: Like many high school athletes, Bobby, 16, a junior from Long Island, has spent years whipping his body into shape through protein diets and workouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cynthia Barnett
title: Crescendos of Crickets and Choruses of Frogs
description: In “Sounds Wild and Broken,” David George Haskell celebrates nature’s trills, calls and peeps.
content: SOUNDS WILD AND BROKEN: Sonic Marvels, Evolution’s Creativity, and the Crisis of Sensory Extinction, by David George Haskell
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: ‘The time has come’: Gov. Murphy of New Jersey ends his daily virus briefings.
description: Friday’s briefing was two years to the day since the state’s first confirmed coronavirus case, the governor said, and served as a fitting end to his pandemic updates.
content: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey held his final daily coronavirus briefing on Friday, announcing that he would lift the state’s public health emergency in the coming week, a significant moment for a state that was an early epicenter of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thor Hanson
title: When Did You Last Clean Bug Splatter Off Your Windshield?
description: It’s probably been awhile — and that’s a problem, Oliver Milman writes in his new book, “The Insect Crisis.”
content: THE INSECT CRISIS: The Fall of the Tiny Empires That Run the World, by Oliver Milman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Build a New City or New Humans? A Utopia in India Fights Over Future.
description: Backed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, the new leadership of Auroville, an experimental commune, wants to create a model city. In the way stand trees, tree houses and a take-it-slow tradition.
content: AUROVILLE, India — The bulldozer arrived one night in December, shaking Ganga Park awake in her tree house and sending her scurrying down the trunk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, William K. Rashbaum and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: How the Manhattan D.A.’s Investigation Into Donald Trump Unraveled
description: The criminal investigation into the former president crashed amid a disagreement about the merits of bringing a case. The debate pitted a new district attorney against two veteran prosecutors who had pursued a case against Mr. Trump for years.
content: On a late January afternoon, two senior prosecutors stood before the new Manhattan district attorney, hoping to persuade him to criminally charge the former president of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Lionel James, Speedy Back Who Covered a Lot of Turf, Dies at 59
description: A diminutive player, he set a single-season record in 1985 for yardage gained in the N.F.L. as a running back, receiver and kick and punt returner.
content: Lionel James, a fast, elusive running back nicknamed Little Train, who shared the backfield with Bo Jackson at Auburn University and set a single-season N.F.L. record for all-purpose yards that stood for 15 years, died on Feb. 25 in Birmingham, Ala. He was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Advertising Acts as Another Vehicle of Protest to Ukraine War
description: Criticism of Russia has become a common feature of advertisements and the marketing industry.
content: As western social media sites tried to block misleading ads coming out of Russia this week, Rob Blackie was trying to sneak ads in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Tim Considine, Young Star of ‘My Three Sons,’ Is Dead at 81
description: He played the oldest son, Mike, after gaining fame in the “Spin and Marty” serial on Disney’s “The Mickey Mouse Club.” But after his 1960s heyday, he faded as an actor.
content: Tim Considine, who was a television star at the age of 14 in Disney’s “Spin and Marty” and went on to wider fame in the family series “My Three Sons,” died on Thursday at his home in the Mar Vista section of Los Angeles. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: On the Scene: Ukrainians protest in Kherson
description: Kherson, in southern Ukraine, was the first major city to fall to Russian forces. On Saturday, street protests presented a challenge to the new authority there. Here’s what happened that morning
content: Kherson, in southern Ukraine, was the first major city to fall to Russian forces. On Saturday, street protests presented a challenge to the new authority there. Here’s what happened that morning
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Network Pool
title: Blinken Pledges Additional Humanitarian Aid to Ukraine
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said that the Biden administration has asked Congress to approve $2.75 billion in humanitarian assistance for vulnerable communities inside Ukraine and refugee services in neighboring countries.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said that the Biden administration has asked Congress to approve $2.75 billion in humanitarian assistance for vulnerable communities inside Ukraine and refugee services in neighboring countries.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Prenatal Tests, Disabilities and the Decision Whether to Abort
description: Readers discuss both the challenges and the joys of raising children with disabilities.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 5, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 5, 2022.
content: An article on Page 1 this weekend about the Brooklyn enclave Red Hook misspells the surname of the real estate mogul for whom a pool in Red Hook was named. He was Sol Goldman, not Goodman.
source.name: The New York Times
